I imagine the pitch for this movie might have seemed rather weak to the wrong Movie Producer, the oddball Coen Brothers directing duo, doing a film set in Dustbowl America, adapted from the Odyssey, starring that guy from ER, with a soundtrack that sounds like it's out of thirties and using cutting edge computer technology to color correct every cell of the film to give it a faded look that will add to the retro thirties effect. And yet the film has been one of the most successful of the Coen Brothers many works, doing well in its theatrical, keeping a devoted fan base to this day, having one of the bestselling soundtracks of all time and for better or worse changing the way movies were filmed for an entire decade. Regardless of how you feel about the movie it revolutionized the industry in a way few have noticed but those that have probably curse, color correction it was the first movie to be shot digitally, transferred to a computer and have the color scheme changed, to saturate the Mississippi landscape and as stated make the cells of the film look faded. It worked pretty damn well at the time for making a unique, and pleasant looking film experience though many probably couldn't have told you why but with the technology out there to be exploited it has basically since been used for mostly evil being the main contributor to the bland blue and orange landscape of the movies today. And not content to start annoying trends in moviemaking it started annoying trends in the music industry as well by popularizing the alright when used properly Producer T Bone Burnett for the now iconic soundtrack. I don't mix music, I can't explain how he does it but T Bone Burnett has become infamous for mixing all the music he produces to give it a lo-fi but high quality sound and after this soundtrack which utilized that for retro effect popularized that every semi folk or country hack looking to get started or make a comeback came to T Bone for a boring lo-fi effect on their record and it took almost ten years for that trend to die. And yet despite the mess it left in its unfortunate legacy, O Brother Where Art Thou? Is debatably the most popular of the Coen Brothers many works, which begs the question why? Is it truly the best among a quite illustrious list? Is it just the most accessible amid a pretty weird catalogue? Or are people just wrong about this one? Let's take a bona fide pater familias look.

Our quick witted and silver tongued protagonist is Ulysses "Everett" McGill (George Clooney, this is one of his best and most unique comic performances) a Mississippi dust bowl conman serving time in a chain gang. Everett is supposedly in prison for robbing an armored car, and the cash which he stashed in his valley Lodge will be under water in four days as the state plans to flood the valley to provide hydro-electrical power to the surrounding area. So he enlists the aid of chain mates Pete (John Turturro, one of his best starring roles he lends a lot of humor as the anger prone one) and Delmar (Tim Blake Nelson, who is damn near inspiring as the loveable simpleton) to break three and set out on a quest across the state to risk life and limb and recover the treasure. Along the way they continually encounter incumbent governor Pappy O'Daniel (Charles Durning, a real comedic highlight as he blows southern spiced gasket over everything) in his quest to defeat reform candidate and anti-big government Homer Stokes (Wayne Duvall, a bizarre and equally hilarious turn as a really freakish character) by harnessing old timey sensibilities. Meanwhile the boys also cut a hit record as the Soggy Bottom Boys with blues guitarist Tommy Johnson (Chris Thomas King, kind of a background performance) who's sold his soul to the devil to play the geetar. But many less savory obstacles await them as they will face traitorous kin, sirens, a bi polar bank robber and one nasty Cyclops (John Goodman, a fun performance but a sad one as well as Goodman said he'd never work with the Brothers again as they constantly cast him in the same roles).

I personally adore this movie and it will always be perfect in my heart, I remember watching it on countless car rides, on a friend's iPod for the first time going to the beach and jamming out to the soundtrack on many occasions. This is why I regret to say it is deeply flawed from a narrative standpoint even for the Brothers Coen. Now don't get me wrong a lot of things about this movie really work and are incredible, the beautiful cinematography, sharp directing, wonderful music, and comedically genius performances but the fact is the story just has too many holes and could definitely have been told better. It quickly establishes a central conflict by giving a countdown saying our trio must reach the valley in four days. But it never establishes how far away the valley is or even why the valley will be flooded till the very end when it doesn't really matter. It gives us a four day limit before the valley is toast but it takes much longer than four days (including a few musical montages of old timey antics) to reach the central conflict and implies afterwards it takes quite a long time from there to reach the valley and not to give anything away the valley floods at the end. Now in all fairness the pretense of getting to the treasure is pretty flimsy as the discerning viewer can tell right away from how vaguely Everett sets up this race against the clock he has some ulterior motive for breaking out but even when they reach the real event for which they escaped more than four days still should have passed. Too give credit where credits do though, the twist of Everett's real motive is perhaps unearned but significantly improves the film in my opinion as well as strengthening the Odyssey parallels and is one of the few movies I can think of the pull of the whole "climax, than wait surprise climax remember this subplot?" ploy. And the Odyssey homages though not direct are really great, maybe this would have been more interesting as a direct adaption into a new setting and time but I was satisfied with a few nods and a basic overall arch and carrying themes of an intelligent man with a lot of vanity and hubris trying to return to his family while first having to reconcile himself spiritually. This is a stylish movie with a lot of nods to the Odyssey and Dustbowl Mississippi culture so it's hard to find that much fault in it when there's such fun to be had. But it is still hard to ignore the messed up timetable and how confusing it is to remember where they're even going or what they're doing...or why they keep losing their cars.

O Brother, Where Art Thou? Has a lot wrong with it and annoyance with it can be understood and perhaps even expected, but through the myriad of glib southern humor there's far too much to be enjoyed about it to hold that against it. It has enjoyable characters, many memorable moments if not a lot to string some of them together and some real heart amid the mess of the story and any movie that can have those accolades heaped on it deserves to be watched. It's certainly not the best Coen Brothers movie, though it may be the most accessible but you can certainly do worse, it is not the worst Coen Brothers movie by far.

Its plot outline is slightly cliched, but its almost universal inventiveness and usually subtle wit already proves enough to formulate a film that places beyond even the Coen masterpiece "The Big Lebowski".

Maybe the perfect adventure film, this instant Coen classic is impossible to turn away from. Though it makes no mistake about its influences - an early title card immediately identifies the picture as an adaptation of Homer's Odyssey - the brilliance of O Brother is in its departures from the source material, which come so frequently that the carryovers (the Sirens, the Cyclops, the protagonist's escape from captivity) are celebrated as nods and winks, expected but also unexpected. George Clooney, John Turturro and Tim Blake Nelson are perfectly cast as the charismatically brainless scoundrels at the story's epicenter, while guest spots from John Goodman, Holly Hunter and Charles Durning take the whole mess over the top. Amazingly rich, sharp-witted, engrossing stuff that's accompanied by an all-time favorite of a soundtrack.

I may be in the minority, but I didn't find this film that great at all. If I were to list pros and cons about O Brother, it would definitely have more pros than cons, but there's something about the aimless story that I can't quite enjoy.

In O Brother, the one thing I admired most was it's aesthetics. Visually, the film is a winner. Scenes that involve the KKK, a tidal wave, and especially three sirens are all constructed absolutely beautifully. The music selection fit the film perfectly and really bolstered what was happening on screen. However, when the cast "sings" it's so terribly unrealistic, it's almost embarrassing. Maybe the was the intent, but either way, I didn't like that it was painfully fake.

But what the actors lacked in competent singing, they surely made up for in acting. Clooney gets a lot of praise for his role, but I honestly thought he did all right. Tuturro and Nelson did a better job at sticking with their accents and remaining in character.

The quirky nature of a Coen's film is there still. Their witty dialogue, unique story, and originality is all present in O Brother, but it's the incoherency in the film that doesn't do it for me.

I'm sure if I watch it more I may be able to appreciate it. It's a great looking film, with enjoyable segments, it's often funny, but nothing ever gets done. It may be because George Clooney is in it haha. I'm not too partial to his acting, but I try to remain objective. 6.5/10

I love the screenplay, the Coen Bros go at it again and this time make an astounding modernized screenplay of a classic Greek Story "The Odyssey". the acting wasn't as great as I'd expect from Clooney but considering he wasn't the actor we all know and love today I'd say he showed some glimmers of what was soon to come.  I also really enjoyed the cinematography, it rightly deserved to get a nomination in this category but should have lost tot "Gladiator" not "C.T.H.D", Roger Deakins delivers an excellent from the entire movie once again.

O Brother, Where Art Tho? is a fantastic Coen Brothers directed comedy that mixes teriffic performances and a fun Homer's Odyssey satire to create a memorable experience.  Its a film with style, heart, and laughs that only the Coens could pull off.  You can't help but fall in love with the wit and charm of the dialogue and the actors, particularly Clooney.  Themes such as racism, redemption, and friendship are touched with great care.  This is a great film that stays with you long after the credits roll, just pure fun all around.
A great movie with a great soundtrack!

My dad's been telling me to see this movie for years, and I finally got a copy of it on saturday for 50 cents. Damn was this good. a highly imaginative retelling of Homer's "The Odyssey" set in 1930's Mississippi. The scene with the Cyclops was undoubtedly my favorite. Add a great soundtrack, and a great cast. this movie is solid gold.

Creative and loose adaptation of The Odyssey, set against the vague backdrop of the Depression era south. It's got your typical Coen Brothers actors, bizarre characters, funny dialogue, and a memorable performance by uber-wiseass/super knowledgeable George Clooney. The country-bluegrass soundtrack is something special too.

Saw it a few years ago and watched it again a few days ago, it's great! I just love that movie :) Great work by the Cohen brothers again. Based on "The Odyssey" I hadn't realised that the first time I saw it !! 
John Turturro is just sooo funny (his little dance in the Soggy Bottom Boys, just hilarious!). 
And it's also a sweet movie, less violent than many other Cohen brothers' movies (as Holly Hunter pointed out in the Making Of). 
Anyway this should really be seen by anyone willing to enter in a world with a bit of fantasy in it :)
This movie is so dang funny it hurts. One of the best soundtracks ever.
Damn, I forgot how awesome this movie is.

Was ok, but I've enjoyed plenty of other films more.  Maybe I'm not clever enough to appreciate these film makers.  Bits were good, but with some very good parts, the whole should have been much better than it was.
I'm a Coen brothers fan from way back, so I admit bias in loving this movie. When I found out that it was based on Homer's Odyssey, I was blown away.

Loosely based on Homers 'The Odyssey', the Coen brothers give us another wonderfully crafted, creative and engaging film. If it weren't for 'The Big Lebowski', this would be the Coen brothers greatest movie. As it is, its a very close second.

Without a doubt Clooney's best performance of his career. He is complemented perfectly by terrific acting from every member of the cast, especially highlighted by Turturro, Nelson, Goodman and Hunter. In addition to its signature Coen brothers quirkiness and script, its often overlooked as a great period piece.

Its bluegrass soundtrack and score work to perfection, and the Coen brothers give us another film which is something you've never seen before, and will never see again.

O Brother Where Art Thou contains many memorable sequences and characters, but never gels together to form a whole. For all the positives, you never really invest too much in what happens to the characters. The film is also a bit too unpredictable, with most sequences coming completely out of nowhere. Still, George Clooney is great as Everett McGill and the film is certainly a unique oddity worthy of your time.

Hard to top this. Something about this whole film is just perfect. "Simple is better' is a Coen recipe that really works well for me, and this film is no different. From the muted colors of the picture, to the wonderful soundtrack, to the great performances, this is a film to remember. A 'Dust Bowl' fairy tale with larger than life characters that seek redemption in their search for freedom. Love this flick!
I really cant pinpoint what I don't like about this movie but parts of it just rub me the wrong way.
The story is not sofisticated or anything like that...it's a simply potted fun movie.
One of the best films of at least the past 30 years! Hilarious, intelligent, and full of wonderful performances by the cast.

What's relieving about O BROTHER, WHERE ART THOU? is the fact that it relies on its over-the-top bizarreness to stimulate an audience with laughter. This is set in the 1930s, mind you, and the characters are far enough off the wall to drive US insane with laughter. One character, George ("not Babyface!") Nelson, has both a violent side and a psychotic side. We see them meld into one personality in scenes such as the one in which he tips his head out of the roof of a car, begins cackling and recklessly firing an automatic weapon.

What's excruciating about this film is that the film goes far enough on a bizarre tangent that it often relies singularly on being an offbeat, wacky comedy, rather than building up a noticeable plot. That is to say, half the time, such as during the scene in which our trio disguises themselves as members of the Ku Klux Klan, we REALLY don't know what on Earth is going on. (And in in the most honest sense, we'd rather be left in lacking of that knowledge.)

The Coen Brothers create this Depression Era Deep South Epic Comedy about three escaped prisoners on an adventure meeting all sorts of colorful characters.  The film draws some inspiration from the Odyssey, but it is so original in so many ways that it outshines any stigma of  being an adaptation.  This film has been one of my favorites since I first saw it, and its beautiful cinematography mixed with a wonderful performances (probably the film that really made me enjoy George Clooney as an actor) and its fun plot don't have me thinking that'll change anytime soon.

I really enjoyed this movie--definitely one of my favorites from the Coen Bros. an awesome spin on Homer's Odyssey that works just as well on its own. the cast, the music, the atmosphere...it's all fantastic.  a great adventure story with cool twists and turns along the way.

I really enjoyed this movie--definitely one of my favorites from the Coen Bros. an awesome spin on Homer's Odyssey that works just as well on its own. the cast, the music, the atmosphere...it's all fantastic.  a great adventure story with cool twists and turns along the way.

Maybe it was supposed to be funny a lot, where as it only worked a little bit. George Clooney does great, he ran the show for me. Towards the middle or so, it starts to pick up. The Odyssey was one of my favorite stories in Greek Mythology, and to see it redone in more modern terms was entertaining in itself. This movie mesmerizes you at points (i.e. the Sirens) and baffles you at others (Big Dan Teague selling bibles), and the acting is superb. This arguably has one of the best soundtracks that I've ever heard, and the success of it was seen at both the Academy Awards and the Grammys that year, with the CD selling close to 10 million alone.

A well-deserved film delight to watch. The Cohen Brothers pulled-off a mainstream hollywood treat that proves Clooney can play a quirky, southern troublemaker. Along with his gang of misfits as the "Foggy Bottom Boys". Zany twists and turns that keeps ya entertained. If I can dig it, you will too.

A rousing and funny romp from the Coens that successfully translates Homer's Odyssey from mythical Greece to the deep South, and shows Clooney to be a solid comedic talent. While the peculiar whimsy so common to the Coens' trademark style may alienate some viewers, O Brother... is still an amusing comedy, backed by a fantastic script (knowing not to take itself too seriously) and even delights visually, largely thanks to Roger Deakins' always impressive cinematography.
